block.p: THE HAGUE: SREBRENICA TESTIMONY -- A former Bosnian Serb general, Radislav Krstic, on trial before the United Nations war crimes tribunal, accused his former commander in chief, Ratko Mladic, left, of personally overseeing the massacre of thousands of Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995. The videotaped testimony was the first time the tribunal had heard evidence directly placing Mr. Mladic, who is still at large, in charge of the forces that carried out the killings.

RUSSIA: OFFICERS DECAPITATED -- Russian officials said that two army officers were killed by Chechen rebels and that their heads were delivered to a military base. On their Web site (www.kavkaz.org), the rebels said they had offered to exchange the two men for a Russian soldier they said raped a Chechen girl.

GERMANY: RIGHTISTS UNDER SCRUTINY -- The government said it would convene a working group to examine the case for banning the far-right National Democratic Party after an outcry over a bombing last week that hurt Jewish immigrants.

SWITZERLAND: BANKS ACCEPT HOLOCAUST DEAL -- Two major banks said they had formally accepted an amended version of a $1.25 billion settlement with Holocaust victims and their heirs. Credit Suisse Group and UBS AG said they had notified United States District Judge Edward Korman in New York of their acceptance of amendments relating to looted art, the further search for bank accounts, financing legal costs and the inclusion of insurance companies.

CHILE: PINOCHET RULING -- The Supreme Court said it will deliver its formal ruling Tuesday on whether Gen. Augusto Pinochet can retain immunity from prosecution, which has blocked bids to force him to stand trial for alleged human rights abuses. The judges voted privately on the case last Tuesday.

HAITI: O.A.S. MISSION -- The Organization of American States' permanent council agreed to send a mission to Haiti to explore ways of strengthening democracy. The action came after an O.A.S. mission concluded that runoff elections on July 9 were flawed because they failed to include races for 10 Senate seats.

PHILIPPINES: ROADSIDE MASSACRE: -- Armed men suspected of belonging to a Muslim rebel group shot and killed 16 people, many of them students, in Cotabato Province after dragging them out of vehicles, officials said. The rebel group, Moro Islamic Liberation Front, denied involvement.
JAPAN: U.S. SOLDIER CHARGED -- The United States Marine Corps indicted Lance Cpl. Kenny Titcomb, 19, on charges that he fondled a 14-year-old girl in Okinawa, military officials said.

INDIA: A STAR'S PLEA -- In a tape cassette sent through an emissary, the kidnapped movie star Rajkumar asked the police not to try an armed rescue to free him from the forested redoubt of the bandit Veerappan. He also asked fans not to use violence to protest his abduction.

INDIA: KASHMIR GROUP ACCUSED -- Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said that arms found at the scene of massacres this week in Kashmir establish that the militant group Lashkar-i-Toiba was responsible. The group has denied any role in the attacks, which killed 98.

NORTH, SOUTH KOREA: MEDIA TOUR -- In another sign that North Korea is shedding its reclusive ways, the heads of South Korean newspapers and broadcast stations will visit Pyongyang today at the invitation of North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il. During a weeklong visit, the delegation plans to meet with North Korean media representatives to discuss exchanges.

NIGERIA: HOSTAGES FREED -- Militant youths demanding jobs in the oil industry released 165 oil workers, including 7 Americans, held hostage since Monday on two drilling rigs in southern Nigeria, the oil company Royal Dutch/Shell reported. Shell has promised to arrange a meeting between the youths and industry contractors to discuss their grievances.

ZIMBABWE: FARMERS SUE -- The Commercial Farmers Union went to court to block the government's planned acquisition of two million acres of white-owned farmland. The union, which represents the nation's 4,000 white farmers, had agreed that underutilized land should be distributed to black peasants but now says the process is moving too fast.

SIERRA LEONE: PEACEKEEPING HELP -- To counter the rebel threat in Sierra Leone, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously to strengthen the 13,000-member peacekeeping force, although the size of the troop increase was not specified. Rebels reignited the nine-year civil war in the West African country in May by seizing about 500 peacekeepers.

FIJI: COUP LEADER IN COURT -- George Speight, along with 12 other rebels, pleaded not guilty in a tightly guarded magistrate's court to minor charges stemming from their May 19 seizure of Parliament and the ousting of the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister. Mr. Speight and his supporters, who requested bail, were remanded for a hearing on Sept. 1.

LEBANON: U.N. DEPLOYMENT -- United Nations peacekeepers started their final deployment along the Lebanon-Israel border. Beirut gave approval after ensuring that Israel had ended its last encroachment.
